results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Netherlands, Switzerland and Wales, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film depicts a trip to the Netherlands and Switzerland, beginning in Welshpool, Wales. It features scenes of “The Dingle” gardens, country fairs, folk dancing, show jumping in Welshpool, Dutch seaside, canal trips in the Netherlands, streetscapes, countryside, farm life, Rotterdam, Spannenburg, bus trip to the Alps, Switzerland, Brienz and Grindenwald.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:40:00 sign “The Dingle” of the Dingle Gardens
00:01:14:00 folk dancing at a country fair
00:02:10:00 horse jumping
00:02:51:00 Dutch seaside featuring people in lounge chairs
00:03:15:00 canal trip through countryside and urban area
00:04:11:00 farm life and creatures including a white peacock, and a young adult in fashionable clothing and clogs holding a skull
00:05:55:00 Commonwealth War Grave sign and cemetery
00:06:05:00 Spannenburg sign shot from a car
00:06:30:00 De Dude Are Museum sign and building shot from boat on a canal
00:07:29:00 in city, people gathering for the arrival of a celebrity
00:07:46:00 three people lining up to eat fish by holding tail up in the air above their heads, in sync
00:07:52:00 miniature theme park featuring tiny windmills, trams, boats, gardens, with one of the boats on fire
00:11:46:00 local market in Rotterdam, possibly; youth fashion
00:14:03:00 bus trip to Switzerland, featuring mountains and countryside scenes
00:16:02:00 feeding bears in a zoo
00:18:09:00 scene of large waterfall
00:20:13:00 Sinclair’s friends having a snowball fight
00:20:58:00 steam train

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie shows the filmmaker and his wife travelling around England in a small yellow mini. They begin in London and travel across England to Stonehenge, up through the south of Scotland up to Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park, back to Edinburgh and end up in Blackpool.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:02:47:00 changing of the Guard
00:05:23:00 Stonehenge – brief look at Stonehenge
00:05:34:00 Stratford-Upon-Avon Cricket Club sign, walking through gardens and a spot of cricket
00:06:58:00 Shakespeare’s Birthplace Trust
00:09:17:00 road trip sign to Penrith, Carlisle and Kendal
00:10:17:00 Fferry trip – Windemere ferry, ’The Ferry House Windemere Laboratory of the Freshwater Biological Association Private Gardens’
00:13:15:00 Loch Lomond Sailings Ltd
00:14:42:00 the Elizabethan Inn – filmmaker and wife meet up with three other women at the inn
00:15:39:00 Tormore Distillery with friends – Long John Scotch Whiskey
00:16:56:00 father and two young girls feeding ducks at a lake
00:17:41:00 Roths Glen Hotel – mini donkeys and friends
00:19:11:00 sign to Pitlochry
00:19:45:00 castle or Military Fort in Edinburgh, guards in kilts
00:20:17:00 cemetery for soldier dogs
00:21:14:00 Blackpool

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description: 7x 16mm film assorted newsreels and home movie. Can of 9.5mm assorted smaller reels. Focus on Ballarat. Family collection by filmmaker John (Jack) Anderson (dec.)
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes from suburban family life in Ballarat and holiday footage from the Mornington Peninsula.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:05:00 a child falling over as he kicks a football in a field
00:05:54:00 two children throw a fully clothed person into a swimming pool
00:08:35:00 slow-motion of three children running and jumping into a pool together
00:19:40:00 footage of child water skiing with Sorrento foreshore and the Continental Hotel in the background

John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes from suburban family life in Ballarat and holiday footage from the Mornington Peninsula.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:05:00 a child falling over as he kicks a football in a field
00:05:54:00 two children throw a fully clothed person into a swimming pool
00:08:35:00 slow-motion of three children running and jumping into a pool together
00:19:40:00 footage of child water skiing with Sorrento foreshore and the Continental Hotel in the background

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents some cinema promotional footage shot at the Ballarat drive-in and a local airstrip along with some shots from a VFL football match.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:14:00 close-up shot of car radio being adjusted for drive-in sound
00:06:15:00 VFL football match at Waverley park including junior footy at half-time
00:08:46:00 airplane taking off with “Superman is coming for xmas” banner behind it

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents footage of the day to day workings of a country Victoria cinema –including black-and-white footage of the Mary Poppins premiere in Ballarat – and group sports in rural Victoria.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 black-and-white footage of Mary Poppins opening at Vegas 70 cinema Ballarat
00:00:45:00 glamorous woman arrives in car
00:01:50:00 the snack stand
00:03:58:00 kids blowing up balloons
00:04:20:00 crowds outside the cinema

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 22]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents holiday footage shot along the Victorian coastline (Portarlington) along with mixed scenes of suburban family life in the 1950s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:08:06:00 Portarlington Post Office sign
00:08:15:00 panning shot of Portarlington Pier
00:08:45:00 woman in 1950s casual wear eating an ice cream in front of a caravan on the beach as she walks toward the camera
00:08:59:00 nice shot on the beach including umbrellas, boat, man lying down and 40s fashion
00:17:31:00 footage of a merry-go-round
00:18:10:00 Christmas tree, children, parents
00:21:28:00 pan across a bay and town with caravan and car in foreground
00:22:08:00 caravan and car in foreground as ship leaves port in the background
00:23:16:00 surfers
00:35:33:00 young girl with miniature Hill’s Hoist toy

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The film contains eclectic footage from a family holiday in New Zealand, a Sherbert concert in Ararat, a Dumbo film premiere promotional parade in Ballarat, and some black and white footage of a surburban house being constructed.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:05:42:00 brief tourist shots in New Zealand: hot springs, tehokowlitu-a-tu, memorial gateway, Maori soldiers
00:07:21:00 shot of a drive-in
00:08:04:00 Astor theatre in Ararat; Sherbert concert footage
00:11:23:00 black-and-white footage of house being built
00:17:52:00 Dumbo film promotion in street parade Ballarat

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents surburban family life in country Victoria along with holiday footage in and around a developing Canberra in the 1950s. It includes some shots of the Prime Minister’s residence, The Lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:27:00 1940s women’s fashion
00:02:09:00 shot of a typical post-war suburban weatherboard home with car in the driveway
00:06:10:00 Christmas with children and their gifts and toys
00:16:10:00 shots from a military air show
00:20:33:00 shot of lounge room and television
00:24:13:00 aerial shots of Ballarat including the drive-in cinema
00:33:33:00 exterior footage of the Lodge and shot of Canberra developing
00:33:16:00 young girl using an old camera over looking a landscape
00:34:34:00 MLC building plaza and surrounds in Canberra
00:35:08:00 shot of old Parliament house
00:35:15:00 shot of the war memorial

description_for_label:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents surburban family life in country Victoria along with holiday footage in and around a developing Canberra in the 1950s. It includes some shots of the Prime Minister’s residence, The Lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:27:00 1940s women’s fashion
00:02:09:00 shot of a typical post-war suburban weatherboard home with car in the driveway
00:06:10:00 Christmas with children and their gifts and toys
00:16:10:00 shots from a military air show
00:20:33:00 shot of lounge room and television
00:24:13:00 aerial shots of Ballarat including the drive-in cinema
00:33:33:00 exterior footage of the Lodge and shot of Canberra developing
00:33:16:00 young girl using an old camera over looking a landscape
00:34:34:00 MLC building plaza and surrounds in Canberra
00:35:08:00 shot of old Parliament house
00:35:15:00 shot of the war memorial

group.title: [John Anderson Home Movie Collection]

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 18]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents a glimpse of suburban family life in country Victoria in the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 Christmas 1967 homemade title card
00:00:13:00 60s Christmas lounge room setting with tree, children and television set
00:02:39:00 reversed footage of girl diving into a swimming pool from a diving board
00:04:54:00 fairground footage
00:09:36:00 close-ups of children eating birthday party food
00:10:08:00 young children dancing at a party
